keyTakeAways: The Amazon Web Services (AWS) outage on October 20, 2025, disrupted a wide range of online services, including social media, gaming, food delivery, streaming, and financial platforms, affecting users globally.
The root cause was traced to issues within Amazon's domain name system (DNS), which converts web addresses into IP addresses, a critical function for internet access.
The outage impacted major services such as Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, Coinbase, Signal, Amazon's own Ring and Alexa devices, and the educational platform Canvas.

Educational institutions such as the University of California, Riverside, and Ohio State University reported that students could not submit assignments or access course materials, demonstrating the critical role of cloud infrastructure in education.

Experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess emphasized that such outages are common due to overreliance on a few dominant cloud providers, and while they are typically resolved within hours, they expose the fragility of modern internet infrastructure.
The event serves as a reminder that the world's digital systems are deeply dependent on a handful of companies, and when one fails, the ripple effect is widespread and immediate.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a major outage on October 20, 2025, beginning at 3:11 a.m. Eastern time and lasting until around 6:00 p.m., when services were restored. The root cause was identified as a failure in AWS’s domain name system (DNS), which disrupted internet access for a vast array of services, including social media platforms like Snapchat and Roblox, financial apps such as Robinhood and Coinbase, streaming services like Netflix and Disney+, and educational platforms like Canvas. The outage impacted users worldwide, including students at major universities such as the University of California, Riverside and Ohio State University, who were unable to submit assignments or access course materials. Experts including Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess noted that such outages are a recurring issue due to the overreliance on a small number of cloud providers, and while they are typically resolved within hours, they expose the fragility of modern digital infrastructure. This incident serves as a critical reminder that society’s digital operations are increasingly dependent on just a few companies, and when those companies face technical failures, the consequences ripple across nearly every aspect of daily life.
